title: Don't you think the Lore is actaully kinda wasted?
body:
I mean, the writing team creates really good stories, actual good charcters with motives and reasons of their own, yet not a lot of people read those stories. Hell, there are people who don't even know what the lore is for the champs they main, it's quite annoying tbh. 
Moreover, the creative team actually make pictures of how the different nations look like, the nature and feel of a nation plus its landmarks, but we can never see them in person, rather we are stuck with the same ol' rift ( with new small changes for each event).
All of that work is really wasted, don't you think so? I mean, every MMO-RPG game creator would love to take all of that work and put it in his game, hell even 1/4 of all this would be still good, yet we get nothing from the lore gamewise (other then feeling a bit cocky when you know a story and a champ more then a person who plays him a lot).
Please, Make something with the Lore.

replies.body: It's kind of in this awkward position for old lore fans where all the stuff they followed is getting retconned left and right. Even if it's objectively of a higher quality it really hurts investment when what you're invested in keeps getting thrown away.

Eh, the game is a constantly evolving game. The old lore that you may have loved was just a shotgun blast of random stories that barely tried to connect to one another, let alone make a believable world. The retconning of the lore is creating a concrete universe for everything to fit into, and that kind of things happens all the time in games and series that are trying to make a more rich environment for it's characters to exist in. There's not really any point in getting hurt over the stories being updated when it's kind of inevitable, like in comic books or videogame sagas, especially since it's for the better of the lore of the game.

Besides, it's nowhere near as bad as printed or physical material getting retconned. Take the Star Wars Expanded Universe for instance. Back in the 90s, the only content we had before and after the Original Trilogy were books that sought to fill the void that Lucas left open. They did a marvelous job with it, introducing beloved characters like Mara Jade, an assassin employed by the Emperor who became Luke's wife, and then Han and Leia's children, Jaina and Jacen. There was also Grand Admiral Thrawn, who attempted to keep the empire alive after Palpatine's death. There were also novels that touched on the Clone Wars as well, though not many. Either way, Lucas Arts made TONS of merch for the Expanded Universe, from card games, video games, action figures, comic books, EVERYTHING - only to have all the stories and content essentially evaporate with the introduction of those trainwreck prequels and Disney's versions of 7,8 and soon 9. So basically, if you loved anything that Lucas Arts made prior to the prequels, every piece of merchandise and book you bought became pointless since the movies basically erased the rich universe that was created.

You know, Blizzard has also been writing a huge ongoing story of the whole universe of World of Warcraft.

Sometimes changes have to be made on the settings of the world history to keep the ball rolling. One of the examples of the change that had been made was the reason of blood elf entering the horde. In some cases, Blizzard sometimes tried to explain that the history wasn't changed, but it's just that the original history is unilaterally depicted by different persons from a different point of view.

But you would never see Blizzard retcon Sylvanas Windrunner to become a completely different person with totally different personality and stories. And you would never see Blizzard say something like "we think that character just had a random boring archetypical story that had no depth in it,  so let's make her the queen of the Alliance instead!"

That's why people are upset. Because the characters (like Karma or Varus) we loved for years, attached to so heavily, were just confirmed by the author that it's nothing but an archetypical story that can be wiped away anytime. And the characters are no longer and will never be himself/herself again.

 And, are those original stories really that archetypical? I can't say about Varus. But for Karma, many fans showed their love towards the old lore on both the Boards and Reddit. I also wrote a full analysis of her old lore, arguing that she was actually a complete character in the old lore, matching her concept design and that Riot had no reason to completely tear that apart.

I didn't discuss Karma, as I didn't know her before her rework. However, Varus WAS super archetypical. It's a plain revenge story of a guy who lost it all, then stole a weapon to get vengeance. It didn't have any depth to it, aside from hoping you identified with him because maybe you have a family too, and you'd get upset if they died. His old lore relied heavily on feelings outside of his story to compel you to like him, it didn't do much at all to build an actual narrative around him and build him as a character in a story. His new lore actually did flesh him out and give him depth of character, and gave us actual stories that revolved around him.

And Blizzard is actually a completely different animal, in terms of narrative. Warcraft has had it's story developed for decades, from the original Warcraft 1, the strategy game. They've done their fair share of retconning, such as making the Dranei not be hideous looking goat people from Outland (as they were in WC3), along with the whole Cataclysm thing that added in classes to races that had no business with those classes, just because "worgen taught dwarves to be shamans" and hogwash like that. They've had a world that was established with rules and races and locations LONG before World of Warcraft came into being, and their narrative exists within that world, progressing the story forward. They don't NEED to evolve or change the story that much, because their world already is very established. 
League, on the other hand, is in the process of establishing their world. It was only a few years back when the new lore initiative began that started to tie the champions together and build the world up so that they all made sense. When you have to actually work to create a living world, as opposed to simply operating within the bounds of one that already exists, you WILL need to make some changes in order to make pieces fit. Once League lore is established, then yes, they won't retcon characters as hard. But until then, expect changes to be made to allow for characters to better make sense in the world that is being built.

Still, all the examples that you cited from Warcraft are about changes in  "world settings" instead of a complete change of character (i.e. denying everything that a character had gone through and all the traits that he/she had gone through). That what I want to emphasize in my previous comment -  retconning stories can also be found in other games, but it is more likely to be in the form of changes in world settings, instead of completely changing an already established main character (i.e. denying all the things that a character had gone through, and changing all the traits that the character possessed). 


Regarding Varus's lore, as I have said, I can't talk about it. That's because I am a fan of Karma instead of Varus. But, let's assume what you said is right - his story was archetypical (P.S. this is totally not the case of Karma under any circumstance). Why didn't Riot try to expand from what he already had to a more in-depth piece? A vindictive character desiring revenge for his/her family can also be seen in classical literature, but their stories were seldom considered as shallow as there could always be twists or more conflictual motivation to add depth to the characters. When there are choices to expand instead of to delete, Riot chose the latter one. And I always believe a character, especially a character in a champion-centric game should be respected as a real living person, instead of someone that can be replaced anytime by another soul.

And for the case of Karma. I think you can try to read her old lore as it wouldn't take so long. I believe Karma is a very well established character with a full set of personality traits, motivation and cohesive behaviors that derived from the former two. She also had been a very appealing character to me and kept inspire me throughout the years.

If you are interested, you can also read my post regarding Karma's old lore and the lore update. It is linked here:
[http://www.evernote.com/l/AU4dhcvBArVLQ6572j-Ym3SbxkzTQ9Tot6I/](http://www.evernote.com/l/AU4dhcvBArVLQ6572j-Ym3SbxkzTQ9Tot6I/)

It is EXACTLY as bad because it is the characters and stories we have in our heads that really matter. The fact that the information is digital just makes it easier for Riot to commit the travesty of deleting what we love.

It still exists, though you'll have to find it on the wiki. But they try at the very least to update a character and stories, and not eradicate them entirely. Sure, they botch it now and again, but what Riot has is an evolving narrative, and not a fixed narrative.

They literally didn't even try with Varus and Swain, Riot publicly admitted this even though they once promised to do a better job and be respectful to their fans. The idea of an evolving narrative meshes poorly with a game that demands an insane amount of time and devotion to play at even a basic level. players who become invested in the characters only to have them deleted on a whim because the writers don't give a shit about the fans basically have all their effort tossed in the garbage and that time they spent wasted.

Riot used to think fans devoted to their game was a good thing, that their posts and criticism represented a passion and love for the game. Now they just ignore feedback that isn't positive and you can find Ghostcrawler hanging out on Reddit shit-talking the boards because this is the only place where players have the courage to point out when Riot screws up.

I can agree with Varus, despite the fact that I personally believe that his narrative went from trite, tired, and boring into something unqiue and different - and I like it - but it did reinvent him completely. 

However, Swain's narrative didn't change a lot. He's still the grand general of Noxus, and his lore is no longer "Swain and his bird eat secrets, shit mystery, and are enveloped in suspense." Instead, they built on his old lore to give it more definition and more of a place in the world. Old Swain was just old leader of Noxus who appeared with a mystery bird and ruled Noxus. New Swain now explains that his bird is now a demon that lives in the Immortal Bastion that Mordekaiser once ruled from, and in exchange for secrets, it grants him a new arm and the power to propel Noxus forward. Old Swain was too vague for the narrative, and that vagueness isn't good for someone who's supposed to be one of the key characters in the grand story arc of the game. The new Swain solidified him and gave him purpose and gave us understanding. It dissolved Beatrice from being one bird to being a hivemind demon raven, and in all honesty, it works much better in the long run. New Swain is also more self propelled and more of a character than old Swain, as we actually get to see his personality and understand what kind of ruler he is. But all in all, his narrative expanded and fleshed him out, it didn't reinvent him. It's hard to reinvent someone who's nothing by an enigma.

Riot needs to make games not just one MOBA game, and what better game to do than an lore focused game set in the Runterran universe.

It is my belief that Riot is sitting on a potential gold mine with their intellectual property that they haven’t even begun to dent. I truly believe that in 10, 20 , 30 years from now Riot could rival the MCU if the play their cards right. Having said that, the DCEU shows us that the success of the MCU, both financially and criticaly, is due just due to beloved characters so I get why Riot is taking their time to build their IP. Hopefully summer 2038 I’ll be lining up at the cinema to watch a block buster about the first Rune War, or a thriller about Jhin’s chilling murders or a buddy movie with TF and Graves. The possibilities are endless. 

Same goes for narrative driven triple A game titles. The idea of playing an open world Wither/TES style rpg in any region in Runeterra excites. The idea of an open world Ionia is particularly exciting since there aren’t that many open world games set in an Asian or Asian-inspired setting. (P.S. This is the reason why I’m so excited for Sucker Punch’s Ghost of Tsushima). 

As for the near future, I think Riot should keep pursuing more comics and shorts stories and look into creating more experimental side project game modes like the Star Guardian and Project events but in the main universe canon.

Edit: I wouldn’t be surprised if Riot is in the early stages of expanding their I.P. or creating new I.Ps as Brandon and Marc aren’t directly involved with the development of LoL anymore. Also, Bioluminescence has the job title “senior level designer” when LoL doesn’t have and levels 🤔

Level designer is a funny old title - it can mean different things based on what studio you're at, or even what you're working on.
SOME studios don't even _believe_ in Level Designers - I think that makes me a mythical creature, which I'm ok with.

Usually it means working on getting the content that the player will ultimately interact with in the course of the game.  So a system in EvE could be created and populated with content by a level designer (or it might be procedurally generated).  A puzzle in an abstract puzzle game could be created by a level designer.  A dungeon in an RPG, or a town in an open world game, or a 'level' in a 2d platformer, or even a track in a racing game.

Sometimes it means making the art, sometimes it doesn't (personally my art skills end at greyboxing).
Sometimes it means programming/scripting the logic, sometimes it doesn't (I am of the scripting variety, when needed).

Usually it involves placing any game-play relevant objects/items - triggers, pickups, spawners, exploding barrels (always exploding barrels), nav points, finish lines, traps, death volumes, smashables, interaction points - those sorts of things!

The end experience of the player - the emotions they feel, the route they take, the story-line they're experiencing, etc - that's all on a level designer.  They're responsible.  If you get lost in a game - that's the level designer's fault!

However, all, some, or none of that might be relevant to what I currently am up to.  
Just explaining what a level designer sometimes does.

I miss the days of the Freljord and Bilgewater events, as does every other player who was present during this time. Those content releases felt epic and rich, and it honestly seemed like Riot was finally incorporating their lore into their game which felt amazing. 

It's all the more disappointing that we haven't seen anything like this return considering the effort they put into their Star Guardian and Project skin lines...

I'll agree that one of the things that has struck me as peculiar in League of Legends compared to most other games is how disconnected the lore feels from the gameplay.  Usually lore in a game serves to create meaningful context for a player's decisions, but I don't even really get how the constant battles on Summoner's Rift fit into the metaplot, how champions who are sworn rivals have no trouble fighting on the same team, why fierce-looking jungle monsters are totally passive until someone attempts to kill them, what minions are beyond pinatas full of gold & XP, etc, etc.

In short, nothing that happens in the game itself makes any sense to me in the context of the lore and it's better for my suspension of disbelief to ignore all of  it the moment I leave the champion select.  It makes League of Legends feel like a spinoff combat game pulling its setting and characters from other established franchises, similar to Heroes of the Storm or Smash Bros.  Or sometimes it kind of feels like Riot has an in-house staff of fanfic writers on the company payroll.  It's weird.

Don't get me wrong, I think the vast majority of the lore is of exceptional quality, and that is probably at least partially due to it being completely unconstrained from having to compromise its excellence to serve the gameplay (and same goes vice versa).  Also, narrative is just one of the many elements that strike me as strangely untethered to League's overall experience (others are where skins fit into this, the game's eSport focus while adopting the visuals & terminology of RPGs, and... well... don't even get me started about how emotes are expected to be used to express anything about the game itself beyond "that was good" and "that was bad").

However, as much as this frees each individual design element to reach its full potential, this also results in an entertainment product whose whole isn't really any better than the sum of its parts.  It's like how a movie soundtrack needs to support and be supported by the visuals and story but even if (or especially if) it's excellent in its own right but incongruous to the other elements it distracts and ultimately detracts from the full movie experience.

Or, to use maybe a more apt metaphor, the various aspects of League of Legends remind me of a team of champions who each are trying to solo carry the game alone rather than cooperate on a shared strategy.
A LoL RPG of some sort would be pretty wicked.
